fact: On new dollar coins, "'In God We Trust' is gone!"

articles.title: 'Godless Dollars' - FactCheck.org
articles.snippet: May 27, 2009 ... Government to Release New Dollar Coins You guessed it 'IN GOD WE TRUST' IS GONE!!! If ever there was a reason to boycott something, THIS IS ...
articles.summary:
A: Congress ordered the words to be stamped on the edges of the coins, but an unknown number of "Godless dollars" were produced by mistake.
Soon a clever reporter began calling coins with missing inscriptions "Godless dollars," and the term has stuck.
Far from boycotting the coins, however, collectors bid up the price of the "Godless dollars" precisely because they are mistakes and, therefore, relatively scarce.
It would be a stretch to call the "Godless" dollars "rare," but they are uncommon.
One eBay seller was offering a "Godless" Adams dollar for $500 as we wrote this, and the same seller was asking $220 for a more common "Godless" Washington dollar.

articles.title: Taking "In God We Trust" off coins was debunked years ago - PolitiFact
articles.snippet: Sep 11, 2012 ... stated on August 28, 2012 in a chain email: On new dollar coins, "'In God We Trust' is gone!" true ...
articles.summary:
I will not take ‘God’ off our coins and I will not take God out of my heart."
The presidential series began in 2007, releasing four coins a year to honor deceased U.S. presidents in chronological order.
Since then, each of the coins in the presidential series has had "In God We Trust" inscribed on the front.
(In 2011, the White House stopped circulating new presidential dollar coins, citing large reserves of uncirculated coins; smaller numbers, with "In God We Trust" still on the front, continue to be produced to satisfy demand from collectors.)
We should note, that it is possible -- though extremely rare -- to find one of the original 2007 coins without the "In God We Trust" side inscription.

articles.title: The U.S. Presidential dollar series: Failure or success?
articles.snippet: Feb 17, 2017 ... “U.S. Government to Release New Dollar Coins. “You guessed it. “ 'IN GOD WE TRUST' IS GONE!!! “Who originally put 'In God We Trust' onto our ...
articles.summary:
Beginning with the release of the George Washington Presidential dollar Feb. 19, 2007, four Presidential dollars were to be issued every year through 2016 at least, and possibly beyond.
At least one example is known of a 2007-D Sacagawea dollar with a 2007-D Presidential dollar edge inscription, making it a design edge mule.
?An annual Uncirculated Dollar Coin set, which contains the year’s Presidential dollar, Native American dollar, and American Eagle silver dollar.
?And several Presidential Coin & Chronicles sets containing, among other memorabilia, Presidential dollars with special finishes and a related medal honoring the same president.
The Presidential dollar proved, again, that Americans do not like to use dollar coins.

articles.title: E-mail claims 'In God We Trust' removed from dollar coins - PolitiFact
articles.snippet: Feb 11, 2010 ... On the new dollar coins, "'In God We Trust' is gone!" true false ... The "new" dollars actually aren't that new. The U.S. Mint says ...
articles.summary:
The latest example comes from a chain e-mail claimingthat newly released dollar coins do not contain the words "In God We Trust".
The U.S. Mint says dollar coins have been minted intermittently since 1794, and there are three in production: the presidential series, the Sacagawea Golden Dollar, and the Native American dollar.
We should note, that it is possible -- though extremely rare -- to find one of the original 2007 coins without the "In God We Trust" side inscription.
Since 2009, all of the coins in the presidential series have had "In God We Trust" inscribed on the front.
You can see "In God We Trust" on the presidential, Sacagawea and American Indian dollars.

The life expectancy of a paper dollar bill is about 18 months, while a dollar coin’s life expectancy is about 30 years.
William Henry Harrison and James A. Garfield are the only dollar coins that feature one date, 1841 and 1881.

fact: Says "over 1 million signatures" were submitted in attempt to recall Gov. Scott Walker.

articles.title: WI Senate Leader Working Overtime to Stave Off Recall | PR Watch
articles.snippet: Feb 8, 2012 ... While the effort to recall Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker ... With a flood of over 1 million signatures, almost 25 percent of the ...
articles.summary:
Wisconsin Senate Majority Leader Scott Fitzgerald (R-Juneau) is in a last-minute scramble to challenge "fraudulent" recall petition signatures.
Of the six public officials facing recall in Wisconsin, Fitzgerald has the slimmest margin of recall signatures.
Last week, Fitzgerald sent out postcards to all the residents within his senate district who signed the recall petition.
Thank you, Scott Fitzgerald for Senate Campaign Team Paid for Committee to Elect a Republican Senate, Scott Fitzgerald, Treasurer"By sending the postcards, Fitzgerald may be trying to determine if an address is fraudulent or flawed.
Problems with recall signatures, most commonly non-complete information, are usually weeded out by lawyers working on behalf of the candidates.

articles.title: 2011 Wisconsin protests - Wikipedia
articles.snippet: ... attempt of Governor Scott ... On January 17, over 1 million signatures to recall Governor Walker were submitted to the state GAB on over 100,000 recall petitions.
articles.summary:
Demonstrations against proposed state legislationThe 2011 Wisconsin protests were a series of demonstrations in the state of Wisconsin in the United States beginning in February and involving as many as 100,000 protesters[3] opposing the 2011 Wisconsin Act 10, also called the "Wisconsin Budget Repair bill."
The protests centered on the Wisconsin State Capitol in Madison, with satellite protests also occurring at other municipalities throughout the state.
[36]The protests and demonstrations began following Walker's introduction of Assembly Bill 11[37][38] to the Wisconsin State Assembly on February 14, 2011.
[253] Jim Palmer, the head of the Wisconsin Professional Police Association, described the action as a violation of the Wisconsin state constitution.
ISBN 9780299293840 A View from the Interior: Policing the Protests at the Wisconsin State Capitol .

fact: "All the billionaires in America, their net worth combined … has increased by $800 billion" during the pandemic.

articles.title: Biden says billionaires gained $800 billion, but study ... - PolitiFact
articles.snippet: Oct 12, 2020 ... “All the billionaires in America, their net worth combined … has increased by $800 billion ... during the pandemic at least to some degree.
articles.summary:
But the impact from COVID-19 on the stock market, for instance, began earlier.
That figure tracks with a study from a left-leaning think tank that uses various numbers provided by Forbes regarding the net worth of billionaires.
For its analysis, the group compared the two, and linked to a spreadsheet that showed the change in the billionaires’ net worth between March 18 and Sept. 15 was $845.1 billion.
To be sure, not all billionaires gained during the time period, and not all billionaires listed had net worth numbers associated with them.
Our rulingCiting a study, Biden claimed that billionaires in America saw their net worth grow by $800 billion during the pandemic.

fact: African-Americans don't use drugs at a higher level than whites but "wind up going to prison six times more."

articles.title: Van Jones claim on drug use, imprisonment rates for ... - PolitiFact
articles.snippet: Jul 13, 2016 ... African-Americans don't use drugs at a higher level than whites but "wind up going to prison six times more." true mostly-true. Criminal ...
articles.summary:
There is also little evidence, when all drug types are considered, that blacks sell drugs more often than whites."
In the late 1980s, the rates were six times higher for blacks than for whites."
Here's the drug arrest rate trend:But Jones was talking about the rates of imprisonment for drug crimes, not arrest rates.
Adjusting for the number of blacks and whites (another approximation because many Americans are of mixed race), the black imprisonment rate for drug offenses is about 5.8 times higher than it is for whites.
Five times more whites are using drugs because there are about 5.5 times more whites in the U.S. population than blacks.)

articles.snippet: African-Americans don't use drugs at a higher level than whites but "wind up going to prison six times more." mostly-true. By C. Eugene Emery Jr ...

Van Jones is a host of CNN's Crossfire.
A former environmental and human rights activist, Jones in 2009, served as the "green jobs" adviser to President Barack Obama.
He is the author of two New York Times best-selling books, The Green Collar Economy (2008) and Rebuild the Dream (2012).

fact: Says ex-Minneapolis officer accused of killing George Floyd commits suicide in prison cell.

articles.title: Officer Charged in Floyd's Death Hasn't Committed Suicide ...
articles.snippet: Jun 1, 2020 ... ... former Minneapolis police officer charged with killing George Floyd, committed suicide in his prison cell. Full Story. As national tensions ...
articles.summary:
Quick TakeA viral story shared on social media is falsely claiming that Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with killing George Floyd, committed suicide in his prison cell.
Full StoryAs national tensions surged over the death of George Floyd in police custody, a dubious website published a story on May 31 falsely claiming that the former Minneapolis police officer charged with killing Floyd had committed suicide.
“Minneapolis Police Officer who killed George Floyd, Derek Chauvin commits suicide in prison cell,” reads the erroneous headline on w24n.com.
SourcesGottfried, Mara H. “Ex-Minneapolis officer charged in George Floyd’s death held in Ramsey County Jail.” Pioneer Press.
“Former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin transferred to Oak Park Heights state prison.” KARE 11.

articles.title: Derek Chauvin, officer convicted of George Floyd's murder, was ...
articles.snippet: Nov 25, 2023 ... Chauvin was stabbed and seriously injured by another inmate inside a federal prison in Tucson, Ariz., according to officials.
articles.summary:
Derek Chauvin, officer convicted of George Floyd's murder, was stabbed in prisonEnlarge this image toggle caption AP APDerek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer who was convicted of George Floyd's murder, was seriously injured on Friday after another inmate stabbed him inside a federal prison in Arizona.
Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison also confirmed to The Star Tribune that Chauvin, 47, was stabbed but remains in stable condition.
In 2021, Chauvin was sentenced to 22 ½ years in state prison for Floyd's murder.
Chauvin, who is white, pinned Floyd to the ground and held his knee on Floyd's neck for several minutes.
Three other Minneapolis officers who helped with restraining Floyd were convicted of depriving Floyd of his right to medical care.

articles.title: Derek Chauvin was stabbed 22 times in federal prison attack ...
articles.snippet: Dec 1, 2023 ... The former police officer was convicted of killing George Floyd during an arrest in May 2020. A WCCO source earlier this week said that ...
articles.summary:
MINNEAPOLIS — The inmate who stabbed former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin in federal prison last week did so 22 times, with an improvised knife, according to recently filed criminal charges.
RELATED: Who is John Turscak, man accused of stabbing Derek Chauvin 22 times?
It's not clear if Chauvin will be moved to a different federal prison.
During both of his federal and state criminal proceedings, Chauvin's defense attorney asked he be sentenced to a federal prison in or near Minnesota to be closer to his family.
Chauvin is now the second high-profile federal prisoner to be stabbed in recent months, after Larry Nassar, convicted of molesting members of the U.S. women's national gymnastics team, was stabbed in a Florida federal prison in July.

articles.title: How much are you airline pilots actually making a year? : r/flying
articles.snippet: Nov 22, 2023 ... I work 91/135 as an FO and work about 200 days a year, make $190k and fly about 700 hours a year. That would put my hourly rate at about $270.
articles.summary:
That would put my "hourly rate" at about $270.
The screenshot above is the Delta hourly rate for 2024.
I have heard, "take the hourly rate and multiple it by 1000."
If you were making $270k a year at a $270 hourly rate, how many days a year is that?
As someone possibly thinking to pursue the airlines, I would love some information since the hourly rate doesn't help me much as I've never done the airlines.

articles.title: At what stage financially do you start flying business/first class? : r ...

articles.summary:

I know it all depends from person to person but my guess is you're probably making 500K+ a year.
Also, what's it usually like for those of you that have to frequently travel for work purposes?
Do your companies usually just buy you normal economy class seats?
Does it depend on your job position as I'd imagine that if you've got a senior role in a big corporation you're most def flying business class for work purposes.

[11][12]HistoryEarly historyThe history of Delta Air Lines began with the world's first aerial crop dusting operation called Huff Daland Dusters, Inc.
Woolman, and other local investors purchased back the crop-dusting assets of Delta Air Service and incorporated as Delta Air Corporation on December 31, 1930.
[20]Delta Air Corporation secured an airmail contract in 1934, and began doing business as Delta Air Lines over Mail Route 24, stretching from Fort Worth, Texas, to Charleston, South Carolina.
[92][93][94]SkyBonusOn November 27, 2001, Delta Air Lines launched SkyBonus,[95] a program aimed toward small-to-medium businesses spending between $5,000 and $500,000 annually on air travel.
Delta Global Staffing was a wholly owned subsidiary of Delta Air Lines, Inc., and a division of the internal company DAL Global Services.

articles.summary:
Top 10 Safest Airlines in the WorldsQantasAustralia’s Qantas Airways is often regarded as the safest airline in the world and was even referenced in the 1988 film Rain Man as having never had an aircraft crash.
The airline was rated seven out of seven stars by AirlineRatings.com but did not make the website’s top 20 safest airlines of 2018.
Hainan Airlines has a fleet of 234 mixed Boeing and Airbus aircraft with an average age of five years.
The airline has never had a fatal crash and was named the world’s safest airline in 2018.
The airline’s aircraft were operated by GB Airways and Air Foyle before EasyJet was awarded its own air operator’s certificate in October 1997.
